block.p: Rescuers Plan to Enter Sunken Russian Sub Rescue teams were preparing a plan to use a ship's crane to rip a hatch off of the Russian submarine Kursk more than a week after it plunged to the bottom of the Barents Sea. They will then begin recovering the bodies of the 118 crew members and try to salvage the submarine's nuclear reactors.
In a Russian navy town, the tragedy of the sunken submarine has rattled residents and brought a hush to the streets.

Festival Draws Young Catholics More than two million young people attended a Mass celebrated by Pope John Paul II in a Rome suburb. The Italian press called the six-day World Youth Festival the ''Catholic Woodstock.''

Finger-Pointing in Poland A former colleague has accused the Solidarity hero Lech Walesa of collaborating with the Communist-era secret services, though he has been formally cleared. The issue of who collaborated has become a charged one for Poland.
Arms Sales Up, Report Says International arms sales surged last year to nearly $30.3 billion, the highest level since 1996, according to a report by the Congressional Research Service.

Progress and Pain in Turkey Villages in southeastern Turkey are being flooded in the final years of a huge public works project. Some people say that the loss of these ancient sites is unavoidable, while others say the price of progress is too high.
Pivotal Election in Chiapas Voters in Chiapas, Mexico, chose a new governor in elections that could end seven decades of rule by the same party and clear the way for talks with rebels.

Iran Seeks to Curb Police Iranian lawmakers approved a draft bill that would bar the police from entering universities without permission. The measure comes after security forces and Islamic vigilantes stormed a dormitory last year and beat up students.
Germans Move Hate Web Sites German far-rightists are transferring their Internet sites to access providers in the United States in order to evade a crackdown by German authorities.

Top Southern Democrats Offer Gore Little Support Several prominent Democratic politicians in the South have been keeping their distance from Vice President Al Gore as they begin their own general election campaigns. Their decisions seem to illustrate the South's general indifference to Mr. Gore's appeal, and demonstrate how hard he will have to work to capture even a few states in the region.

Mr. Gore renewed his attacks on drug companies and health maintenance organizations and vowed to bring broader and fairer health coverage to all Americans. Campaigning in Illinois and Iowa, Mr. Gore also said he would push for a patients' bill of rights to protect HMO consumers and for adding a prescription drug benefit under the Medicare program.

A senior adviser to Mr. Gore accused Gov. George W. Bush of trying to dodge, or at least minimize the impact of, presidential debates, while one of Mr. Bush's top aides said the governor was willing to debate but was still considering more than 40 invitations from an array of potential sponsors.

A Scare Led McCain to Act Senator John McCain was recovering at the Mayo Clinic Hospital in Phoenix, awaiting a determination by pathologists on whether the melanoma removed from his temple had spread. Mr. McCain's experience with a delayed response to his first melanoma in 1993 led him to act much faster this time.

New Jobs for Lumberjacks As high-tech companies face labor shortages in cities, they have begun to branch out to areas passed over by the boom, bringing jobs and training. But for places like Coos Bay, Ore., once a center for the wood-products and fishing industries, there are painful twists. Many new jobs pay less than the old ones and require people used to physical outdoor work to sit at computers.

Meeting on Airline Problems Secretary of Transportation Rodney Slater has summoned airline executives, union leaders and airport officials to a meeting today to try to reach agreement on ways to improve airline travel in the wake of a record number of flight delays and cancellations.

Power Failures Persist About 1,800 North Carolina homes and businesses were still without electricity as crews worked to restore service knocked out Friday by severe storms. Authorities blamed the storms for two deaths.

New Police Commissioner Reaches Out to Minorities Bernard B. Kerik, New York City's new police commissioner, visited a black church in East New York, Brooklyn, where he asked the congregants to ''give me a chance'' to succeed. He said he has told officers that wrongdoing would be punished. But he also said that mistakes by officers need not inflame relations with the community if there is understanding and respect on both sides.

Complaints for Spanish TV The nation's fastest-growing television audience watches Univision Television Network and Telemundo Network Group, the two Spanish-language networks. In New York, the Univision affiliates now draw higher ratings than some English-language stations. But the networks are also criticized for a lack of dark-skinned Latino employees and for using too much imported programming.

Tourists Flow to Hudson Valley Tourism officials say that after years of getting lost between the hyperkinesis of New York City and the tranquility of New England, the Hudson Valley seems to have arrived. Tourism is at an all time high, with the amount of money spent on lodging almost doubling in 10 years. Some 25 million people visit the Hudson Valley a year, and their spending adds about $2.5 billion to the local economy.

Winning Streak Continues Tiger Woods beat Bob May in a three-hole playoff to win the 82nd P.G.A. Championship, his third straight victory in a major tournament. Woods overcame a two-stroke deficit in the final round to force the playoff.
Harry F. Oppenheimer The South African gold and diamond magnate who used his wealth and influence in the fight against apartheid, he was 91.
David N. Edelstein A federal judge in Manhattan who sat on the bench for nearly half a century, he was 90. He presided over some of the Justice Department's most historic cases.

Deal to End Verizon Strike Verizon and the two unions representing about 50,000 telephone workers reached a contract agreement to effectively end a 15-day strike. Talks with representatives for about 35,000 other workers were continuing. The unions secured numerous concessions from Verizon, including the right to more easily attempt to organize workers in its wireless division, and a salary increase.

Grisly Confessions on TV Court TV, the cable channel devoted to the criminal justice system, will begin a series next month called ''Confessions'' featuring actual videotaped confessions of murderers, rapists and other offenders.

Many Take, but Few Give A survey of music downloaders on the Internet who use programs like Napster and Gnutella found that, rather than sharing, most users are only taking files and do not give any to their electronic community.

Split Views on Internet Privacy While most consumers who use the Internet are concerned about their privacy online, a new survey found, many also said they were willing to share personal information with the Web sites they used. And many said they did not take advantage of tools to protect themselves.
Soda Maker Offered for Sale Britvic, one of Britain's largest soft-drink makers, is for sale as part of a strategy by Bass to focus on its hotel business.
